title: Lendlease cleared to build last Barangaroo project
text:
"In terms of Sydney, there’s not much like it – high-quality precinct integrated into the city. It’s creating a new precinct in Sydney and the prices are being reset accordingly."

The state’s Independent Planning Commission (IPC) this month approved the development application of the last tower of the state significant development, a 30-storey residential and retail building on a 1750sq m site near near the intersection of Hickson Road and Watermans Quay.

Another view of the Lendlease's three final Barangaroo apartment towers. Supplied

The tower will yield 210 apartments including 48 key-worker units and 871sq m of retail space.

The tower joins its two sister towers, at 72 storeys and 60 storeys with 327 and 297 units respectively, approved in 2017.

All three buildings, designed by Pritzker Prize-winning architect Mr Piano, will have ground floor shops and amenities.

"The Commission also notes the international design credentials of the eminent architect," the IPC said in a public release.

The IPC said it gave the precinct the green light because it would deliver not just design excellence but provide a “high quality public domain”, “positive social and economic benefits” and “provision of quality housing and retail accommodation”.

Advertisement

Council objections

These selling points were not echoed by the City of Sydney, which objected to all three towers' planning.

Render of One Sydney Harbour. Supplied

With the first two towers, the council was concerned the density of the units and the layout of the towers could lead to “poorly planned apartments”.

The council says the “built form” of the last tower will not "interface well" with the public domain, leading to increased noise, traffic and parking problems.

That wasn't the only hurdle.

The progress of the project had also been impeded by Lendlease and Crown Resorts' two-year joint legal battle against the state’s former Barangaroo Development Authority over blocked views of the Sydney harbour and bridge.

The government’s deal to build a much taller Barangaroo Central, a separate housing and commercial precinct and the last piece of developable land in Barangaroo, went against agreements with the two companies over the preservation of “sight lines”.

Advertisement

But Lendlease and Crown won the case late last year and NSW’s decision to drop its appeal in early August paved the way for Lendlease to seek approval for the final tower.

Given backlash to its development from council, all three applications found their way to the IPC.

The 30-storey building will sit behind the two taller towers at Lendlease's One Sydney Harbour development at Barangaroo. Supplied

The three towers are now poised to alter Sydney’s skyline and liven its street-level surroundings with new retail activity, energising the area which shares a boundary with historic precinct The Rocks.

The two taller towers will be connected by a covered, glazed pedestrian link bridge for residents, as well as a pedestrian thoroughfare called the Strada.

The Strada, which connects Hickson Park and Watermans Cove, will itself be a retail laneway.
description: Developer will be able to price new residential precinct  One Sydney Harbour on global, not local, standards.
